lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about the owner of an eight-table Italian restaurant on the cusp of a major decision. Carlos Vega bought the 900-square-foot Father and Son Pizzeria in Guttenberg, N.J., in 2007 and worked long hours perfecting the restaurant’s house sauce, expanding the menu options and building a vibrant takeout trade. Though the business was profitable, revenues plateaued well short of where he had hoped. Two years in, Mr. Vega found himself debating the pros and cons of two very different paths forward.

Its stock recently took a beating amid concerns of slowing profit growth from smartphone sales, and the company is under pressure to continue releasing innovative new products to compete with Apple and a crop of handset makers in China. lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is starting the year the same way it ended the last one: by whipping out its wallet, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The bank is preparing to reach roughly $2 billion in criminal and civil settlements with federal authorities who claim that it ignored signs of Bernard L. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme, bringing its settlement total to nearly $20 billion over the last year. The settlements come on the heels of a record $13 billion deal with the Justice Department in November related to the bank’s questionable mortgage practices leading up to the financial crisis.

lead_paragraph: I THINK I have flown on every airline existing on the planet at least once. Family members and people I work with call me a “risk” because I too often barely make it to flights on time. I like to maximize the time I have, so I do cut it close. On two occasions I had to get out of a taxi and walk along the highway, roller dragging behind me, briefcase tightly tucked under my arm and cellphone blasting calls for help, just to be sure I made my flight.

lead_paragraph: Prosecutors had long hoped Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, would provide the missing link in their pursuit of the hedge fund’s owner, Steven A. Cohen. Instead, the insider trading case prosecutors never thought would happen is going to trial, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Prosecutors first confronted Mr. Martoma in November 2011, asking him to cooperate in their long-running investigation of Mr. Cohen, and they have continued to press him in a number of meetings since. But Mr. Martoma has baffled officials by refusing to cooperate against the boss who fired him in 2010.

On Tuesday, Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, imposed a record $1.7 billion fine for felony violations of the Bank Secrecy Act for failing to report Bernard L. abstract: A smaller trade deficit, increased consumer spending and a surging stock market contributed to a revised outlook for United States growth.

lead_paragraph: When money market mutual funds were invented back in 1971, they offered something new. Investors could earn higher yields than on bank deposits, with nearly the same liquidity and safety. But that has changed. Currently, a money market deposit at Citibank pays about five times as much interest as an investment in the Fidelity Cash Reserves fund — though, in today’s low-rate environment, the yields are minuscule.

lead_paragraph: IN a world where time-pressed people type “u 2” for “you too”; say “because” to introduce a noun or adjective rather than a full clause, as in “because doughnuts;” and use abbreviations like “ftw” (“for the win”), marketing and media phrases are also increasingly being compressed. The banking giants, analysts say, will most likely face sluggish demand from borrowers whose appetite for refinancing has been sapped by rising rates. For JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s largest bank, the quarterly report comes after a string of costly government settlements, prompting analysts to predict that high legal costs could hamper profit. abstract: When asked how much sleep they “usually” get, Americans estimate just 6.8 hours. When asked to document their sleep the night before, slumber time jumps to 8.7 hours.
snippet: When asked how much sleep they “usually” get, Americans estimate just 6.8 hours. When asked to document their sleep the night before, slumber time jumps to 8.7 hours.
lead_paragraph: A couple years ago I wrote about how people don’t work nearly as many hours as they claim they do. That is, there’s a big gap between how many hours people estimate they “usually” work versus how many hours they log when asked to keep a time diary, especially for people who already keep long hours. (The typical person who reported having worked 40 hours, for example, actually worked about 37; people who claimed a usual week of 75 hours worked 50.) This discrepancy could be due to fuzzy memories, or a desire to sound more industrious, or both.

headline.main: You Sleep More Than You Claim You Do

World leaders scheduled to attend the forum include Shinzo Abe, prime minister of Japan; David Cameron, prime minister of Britain; Benjamin Netanyahu, prime minister of Israel; and Hassan Rouhani, president of Iran. The United States will be represented by Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary; Penny Pritzker, secretary of commerce; and Gina McCarthy, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, who will discuss President Obama’s climate action plan. This year’s celebrity in residence is Matt Damon, who will receive an award for his charitable work. Some of the speeches and panels will be posted on the forum’s website, weforum.org.

abstract: Paramount Pictures became the first major Hollywood studio to stop delivering movies on 35-millimeter film in the United States, offering them only in digital format, The Los Angeles Times reported.
snippet: Paramount Pictures became the first major Hollywood studio to stop delivering movies on 35-millimeter film in the United States, offering them only in digital format, The Los Angeles Times reported.
lead_paragraph: Paramount Pictures became the first major Hollywood studio to stop delivering movies on 35-millimeter film in the United States, offering them only in digital format, The Los Angeles Times reported. The change reflects a shift toward use of digital projection. Only about 8 percent of about 40,045 United States theaters screens are equipped to show movies only in a film format, according to the National Association of Theater Owners, The Los Angeles Times said. Statistics compiled by the Motion Picture Association of America showed that the number of nondigital screens in the United States dropped to 6,387 by the end of 2012, from 33,319 in 2008. The last Paramount picture delivered to some theater owners in a film format was “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues,” The Times reported. Many of the remaining film-only screens are in small towns, where owners have been hard pressed to afford a conversion.

headline.main: Paramount Takes Step With Digital Film
headline.print_headline: Paramount Takes Step With Digital Film

abstract: A rough calculation suggests breaking up Dow Chemical could increase its value, so investors reacted favorably to a suggestion that the company split off its petrochemicals business, writes Kevin Allison in Reuters Breakingviews.

lead_paragraph: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb is putting the right accelerant into Dow Chemical. Shares of Dow jumped more than 7 percent at one point on Tuesday after Mr. Loeb called for a split of its petrochemicals and specialty chemicals businesses. lead_paragraph: At the beginning of last year, I started using a new technique to analyze my numbers: the trailing sum or average. In a nutshell, you track a set of numbers looking back from the present, at regular intervals, and see how the results change over time. Doing so shows patterns that can be hard to see if you are used to looking at calendar years — it’s as if every month represents the end of the year. It also smooths out variations in shorter time periods. Over all, I find it a useful way to track progress.

headline.main: How We Increased Productivity on the Shop Floor

abstract: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear.
snippet: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear.
lead_paragraph: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear and software from like Cisco Systems and Hewlett-Packard. While that is unlikely to be a huge business soon for Dell, it lends credibility and muscle to what has been a growing effort to dislodge these incumbents through cheaper, easier-to-build equipment. If Dell and others can do that, a result would be lower costs at the large data centers run by Google, Facebook and large banks and companies. Cheaper networking could also make the Internet even more ubiquitous.

headline.main: Open-Source System to Be Offered by Dell

abstract: Thirty-four years ago, Donna Speigel opened a consignment store in Cincinnati. Today she has 11 stores, 90 employees and annual revenue that she said exceeds $5 million.
snippet: Thirty-four years ago, Donna Speigel opened a consignment store in Cincinnati. Today she has 11 stores, 90 employees and annual revenue that she said exceeds $5 million.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps fittingly for a onetime director of guest relations at an amusement park, Donna Speigel has turned the Snooty Fox chain of shops — consignment shops, no less — into Cincinnati destinations. Her customers come from as far away as Indianapolis and Louisville, even paying $25 to reserve a seat on “Fox Hunt” tour buses, where they are served boxed lunches and company lore. At the stores, they get wine and dessert and typically shop, if not until they drop, at least until they have taxed the bus’s overhead racks and lower storage compartments with their purchases.

lead_paragraph: We just published an interview with Donna Speigel, owner of the Snooty Fox chain of consignment shops. Last year, the 11 stores rang up more than $5 million in sales. As Ms. Speigel explains in the interview, she has turned her Cincinnati-area shops into destinations that routinely lure people on tour buses from as far away as Louisville and Indianapolis. But Ms. Speigel has also been creative on another front. In 2006, she opened a nonprofit school for people with special needs in Covington, Ky. called the Conductive Learning Center of Greater Cincinnati. Moreover, the school is largely funded through special Snooty Fox initiatives, notably a popular platinum credit card.

lead_paragraph: When Morgan Stanley’s share price fell to $20 in 2011, the bank’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, and several of his top lieutenants tried to encourage investors by buying up stock with their own money. Now, that put-your-money-where-your-mouth-is approach appears to have paid off.

headline.main: Morgan Stanley’s Stock Bet Yields Windfall on Paper

abstract: The Puppy Bowl, now in its 10th year as counterprogramming to the Super Bowl, is joined this year by the Kitten Bowl and the Fish Bowl.
snippet: The Puppy Bowl, now in its 10th year as counterprogramming to the Super Bowl, is joined this year by the Kitten Bowl and the Fish Bowl.
lead_paragraph: The Puppy Bowl has long been the big dog when it comes to alternative programming during the Super Bowl. When the stadium lights went out at the big game last year, more than a million viewers filled the time by flocking to the canine contest.

headline.main: Super Bowl Sideshows Starring Puppies, Kittens and Fish
